Here is a fact about white phosphorus
America in ww2 really loved using white phosphorus as a weapon (in the same way as napalm in vietnam war) they where put into bombs and artillery and in som sherman tanks they used white phosphorus smoke shells (smoke in ground warfare is used for cover and smoke shells are a smoke grenades fired by tanks from their gun rather then a small external tube or smoke mortar the point is to block the enemies sight rather then cover yourself and allow yourself to get flanked white phosphorus was the same except it had the advantage of destroying tanks that could not be penetrated by shells a normal gun can fire) american use of white phosphorus was questionable at best and considering the soviets already defeated the nazis and where having no trouble dealing with the leftovers (in some times during 1944 the Soviets where having a such a field day it was considered dishonourable and unmanly to die) the western front and as such the american use of white phosphorus could have been avoided as a whole (and actually would have ended with less people dead on the allied front since the west couldn’t properly deal with the fascists) so for some people i don’t recommend making white phosphorus unless a list is where you want your name to be same with tungsten and depleted uranium

Red phosphorus strips are easily dissolved into ethanol.
My advice would be to soak the box in water, strip the thin layer of paper from the box and soak it in alcohol above 70%. Once you've dissolved it, evaporate the alcohol, and grind it. You get a uniform powder with a high degree of purity.

I used to do this magic trick with matchbox scrapings where you set a small pile alight, then, once it's DEFINITELY stopped burning and cooled(yes, learned this the hard way), then you rub it between your fingers and magic smoke is produced.
You can even apply the phosphorus ash to your fingers, wash the burnt colour of your fingers with some water, and when it dries you can STILL get the smoke when you rub your fingers together.
IDK how safe it is to do, but it's a pretty cool magic trick.

I used to make my own “strike anywhere” matches. Strip the striker pad, dip match head in water and roll in the phosphorus. When it dries, the matches will strike on any slightly rough, hard surface. Stone, concrete, leather shoe soles etc.
Probably not very safe if you were to carry around in your pocket though. I think they could ignite off each other.

I worked at The Ohio Match Company in the Chemistry Lab in the early 70's before they shut down.
The striking strip on the boxes or book is 50/50 Carbon Black and Red Phosphorus. The match tip has KCLO3 and sulfur (and other stuff) and when the two meet the friction ignites the match.
Strike anywhere Kitchen matches the tip is KCLO3 and Red Phosphorus. Friction on a rough surface will ignite the mixture. Even shaking the box hard enough will do it.
I still know the composition mix for the matches, but not the exact proportions, it's been 50 years after all.

Ok dude you obviously dont know your head from a hole in the ground you cant make white from red but you can make red from white. I actually goes white to yellow to red to black. Cut the striker strips put in cup full of acetone aggitate with paint stirrer the remove the cardboard put acetone and red in a corning vision ware type pan heat on electric burner until the red releases the waxes and glues and the red will form a pattern in bottom of pan that looks like the electric burner turn off heat wait for it to cool scrap waxes and glues off top of container the filter your red out. You will have a beautiful fine red powder nice and clean

I found another way to extract red phosphorus from matchboxes with less manual labour.  With ethanol (I used 90% last time but been successfully doing this with 70%) i just stirred them in beaker and all red phosphorus came out from cardboard nice and easy. After this just filter it or boil ethanol and water away. I did this to about 100 matchboxes and it took me about 15 minutes.

I once did an experiment reducing lithium phosphate with magnesium powder.  Igniting the powder mixture produces a well-behaved reaction that produces no gasses and burns slowly and completely.   Interestingly, there was a red crust on the top which I later realized was the white phosphorous produced internally converted to red via the high temperatures. I didn't really know what to expect. All I knew was that you store phosphorous in water.  So, dumping the remaining product into water instantly produced popping and flaming and a smoke that smelled like garlic. I moved that somewhere away to finish and didn't mess with it any more.  However, I did read later that this reaction produces "some substance", that when combined with water, produces phosphorous pentoxide. Given that P05 smells like garlic, I assume that it what happened.  Once the reaction with the water is spent, you are left with a sort of gray powder which I suppose is a mixture of Li and Mg oxides among other things.

You should try making elemental phosphorous by way of the carbothemal reduction of calcium flouroapitite with silicon dioxide and a carbon source such as activated charcoal, It takes place at 1,200 - 1,400*C.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carbothermic_reaction

4Ca5(PO4)3F + 18SiO2 + 30C → 3P4 + 30CO + 18CaSiO3 + 2CaF2

I realize that 1,200*C sounds kinda hot but a steel retort with a throwaway reaction chamber like a paint can immersed in a fire pit with a blower could easily reach that temp, and then of coarse if you could find a suitable solvent for calcium fluoride you could recycle that to react with more tricalcium phosphate and make more fluoroapitite. I know you could easily substitute the fluoroapitite for sodium hexametaphosphate and the carbon for aluminium powder but thats already been done before. Perhaps to ambitious for your channel i dont know but it would be really cool to see :D

A more efficient method of extracting the red phosphorus is to first get a beaker about half full of acetone
Then with scissors, cut the striker strips off the side of the matches boxes and place them in the acetone
Then get a drill with a kitchen beater attached and use that to mix the acetone and strikers
After about 5 minutes of mixing, all the red phosphorus will have come off the cardboard
Then all you need to do is strain off the cardboard and give it a final washing to remove any residual red phosphorus
Then filter the liquid and you will be left with a decent amount of red phosphorus on a filter paper which can easily be scraped off
Hope this helps
